comment: It is pretty good, but not anything to write home about. Don't forget that it's from Texas, that is apparently very important.
This whiskey is very drinkable, has considerable body and a little biting finish. It tasted more like a Canadian blend than a bourbon.
Smooth, if not too smooth. Not much of a flavor profile, but nothing objectionable either. Whiskey for wine drinkers?
Smooth, but forgettable. Nothing stands out as a characteristic aroma or taste. Decent, but there are better whiskeys from Texas to be had.
Interesting and flavorful but I disagree that this is a smooth whiskey. It certainly has a bite to its finish.

Nose of caramel, cream and light smoke.  Thinner body; sweeter taste.  The flavor is not distinct in any way.  Touch of spice towards the finish, which is short to mid.  Best mixed with 7 Up.  Not top shelf; but a bit above bottom shelf swill.
I actually thought this was pretty good - very smooth, a bit thin but nice spice. Not bad.
Mesquite spice, light honey, filmy after-taste.  Thoroughly average.
Light and smooth. Peppery spice upfront. Vanilla, caramel and a bit of smoke.
Smooth, very light.  A bit of spice, pepper. Light vanilla, caramel, smoke.
Has a strong sweet caramel nose. Sweet caramel flavor. Oak & caramel finish that warms on the way down. Nice lingering warmth. Batch 2. Bottle #11341.
Bananas and woody. Like angels envy.
Smoother than jack, makes for an EASY drinking cocktail. Recipe of choice at the distillery was Rebecca creek, Canada dry, and a lime... "Texas Mule".
While in San Antonio I decided to try it, nothing to write home about unfortunately. Tasted a bit watered down with a hint of sweaty sock about it.
Slight spice, mostly vanilla, not as sweet as TX, but that's good.
Nothing noticeable, wouldn't order it again.
A little thin at first, but turns sweet and oaky. Not bad
Tastes more of spirits with a whiskey after note. Not a fan.

Color: The color on this blended Texan is a light caramel brown. The legs are really watery and thin.

Nose: On the nose I find notes of caramel, oak, sweet butterscotch or cotton candy, salted nuts, and the overall impression of a dry white wine; it has an alcohol mixed with sweet fruity sort of presence.

Taste: The palate on this whiskey features notes of leather, buttered toast, corn, and a slight strawberry and cherry note reminding me of Twizzlers candy.

Finish: The finish is quick to medium in length, leaves me with little to no burn, and has afternotes of red apples with cinnamon, basically an impression mom’s apple pie. How much more American can you get?

Thoughts: For this proud Texas spirit, I paired this whiskey with a bowl of carne asada fries, so needless to say, it was a fine afternoon. As far as the whiskey itself, I found it relatively complex and very interesting. There were tastes in this whiskey I hadn’t found anywhere else, and I was pleasantly surprised. I like it! Thumbs up, Rebecca Creek! Cheers!

Ryan: Light sweet nose. Vanilla flavor profile. Slightly sweet front with minimal alcohol burn. Finish is slightly lingering with a good pepper taste. 

Evan:
Mild fruit with a little burn.
Who in the world adds vodka to whiskey and sells it.  Did not like this at all.  It was difficult to choke down even with Coke.  I gave it one star because it did give me a buzz.
slightly sweet, not a long powerful after taste
very smooth and light.  at ankurs on xmas
Very, very smooth.  Sweet, light, and very thin.  It won't disagree with anybody, but really doesn't stand out.  Gentle vanilla cream, a hint of oak.  Somewhat herbal on the nose.
Yeah, I guess I just don't get the appeal of spirit whiskeys. Youthful and bland overall with a bit of vanilla. If this is your thing, just fork over the extra $5 and get a TX Blended.
Really bitter notes on nose and palate. Tastes like there is some very young whiskey in the blend.
Asked for it neat but they poured it with ice, can’t taste much of anything. Also could be because I just ran a marathon. Will not try again.
Sweet smell, but thin body and high burn. Might be okay as a well but not at all a fan.

Way more ethanol on the nose than you’d think for an 80 proof. Same on the palate. Simple. Vanilla, oak, ethanol. The finish is slightly unpleasant. It has an odd flavor that tastes synthetic. It’s like vanilla frosting that is very sweet and has been left out of the fridge for about a day. If you want to feel like you’re getting more drunk than you actually are, drink this. Or if you want a headache. Otherwise, stay away.
Visited tasting room a few weeks ago and had a flight of beverages.  All good.  Later found bottles at local store and confirmed Rebecca Creek is smooth.
Fairly warm and sweet up front with hardly any burn throughout. Tastes what I would think the color amber should taste like and has mild earthy and fruity notes.
Smooth, just enough bite, not too harsh (bookers/knob), easy for weekend drinking both neat and mixed.
A mellow taste with a hint of fruit. Very low proof makes this an easy drinker. No real bite.
